title: 114_hr6293
content: The Act titled the "Fair SHARE Act of 2016" or the "Fair Salary History Alternatives for Responsible Employment Act of 2016" addresses unlawful employment practices related to salary history of applicants. The "Fair SHARE Act of 2016" prohibits employers from inquiring about an applicant's salary history, except when an offer of employment has been made and the applicant volunteers the information with written authorization. The Commission must issue rules regarding the exception under section 2(b) within 1 year of the Act's enactment, and enforcement provisions are outlined in section 4. Employees covered by Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 are provided with powers, procedures, and remedies for unlawful employment practices. Costs and fees related to violations are outlined in specific sections of the Revised Statutes of the United States. The powers, remedies, and procedures provided in the Revised Statutes of the United States (42 U.S.C. 1988) and section 1977A (42 U.S.C. 1981a) apply to the Commission, the Attorney General, or any person alleging unlawful practices, excluding certain employment practices. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 covers employees with its own powers, remedies, and procedures. The powers, remedies, and procedures under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply to the Board or any person alleging a violation, except for certain cases. Costs and fees are covered under subsections of the Revised Statutes of the United States for such practices. The powers, remedies, and procedures under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply to the Board or any person alleging a violation, except for certain cases. Title III of the Act applies to claims of practices described in paragraph (1) in a similar manner as it does for violations of section 201(a)(1). The powers, remedies, and procedures under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 apply to claims of unlawful employment practices against certain employees, as outlined in Title III of the Act. The powers, remedies, and procedures provided in sections 722 and 1977A of the Revised Statutes of the United States apply to claims of unlawful practices, including damages and limitations. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 covers employees in this regard. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices. These provisions apply to employees covered under this Act, with exceptions outlined in the text. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices, including damages and coverage under specific sections of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Act specifies the powers, remedies, and procedures for the Commission, Attorney General, and Librarian of Congress in cases of unlawful employment practices. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 provides powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Damages for such practices are outlined in section 1977A of the Revised Statutes of the United States. The Government Employee Rights Act of 1991 outlines powers, remedies, and procedures for employees alleging unlawful employment practices under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Section 1977A of the Revised Statutes of the United States specifies damages for such practices. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) is defined in this Act. The term "employer" includes various entities as specified in different sections of related laws. The term "employee" includes various categories of individuals under different sections of related laws, such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995. The term "person" in the Civil Rights Act of 1964 applies to employees under various related laws. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 defines "person" to include employees under related laws. This Act will become effective one year after its enactment.
